Description: Pale green quartz (?) unfinished seal-stone (?), with the base cut straight and the top rounded. The cross-section would be rectangular if the vertical edges had not been bevelled off, causing them to taper towards the top. Both small sides were accidentally chipped near the top, as the maker clearly attempted to drill a horizontal suspension hole. Once broken, the object was left unfinished, which explains why the base has not been carved with a design or inscription.
Findspot: Found/Acquired: Tell Dafana, Probably from the North-west Ptolemaic mound
Curator's comments: One of the "four plain seal-stones unengraved, one broken in drilling (...) three of pale green translucent calcite (...), of Syrian type", mentioned by W.M.F. Petrie, Tanis ii, Nebesheh and Defenneh, p. 74 § 70, p. 111, pl. xli, 74. See also London, BM, EA 18469 (glazed composition) and Boston, MFA 87.710, 87.711
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1888 / Tanis. Part II. Nebesheh (Am) and Defenneh (Tahpanhes) (p. 74 § 70, p. 111, pl. xli, 74)
Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.67, pl. 24)
